Brazil has something to fear.
The Temer government, of the coming and going, is showing the one that came: while extinguishing the rights of all, it distributes benefits to a few
Now, the acting Finance Minister wants to stop Brazil. He wants to dismantle health and education and dismantle social security.
It claims in a phony manner that health, education and social security expenditures in recent decades have made it impossible to control expenditure more.
Well, Mr. Minister, were spending on education and health that improved the quality of life of the population.
Contrary to what the provisional government seems to think, spending on health and education in Brazil is still low.
For Brazil to become a Country and a developed Nation, it will have to invest much more in education and health than it did.
In the last 13 years, we have tripled spending on health and education.
We have created a real passport for the future by allocating the resources of the Pre-Salt Social Fund to these areas.
Education is the way to reduce inequalities, initiated in the last decade.
At the same time, education is the path to the knowledge economy, sustaining the development of science, technology and innovation.
The acting Finance Minister seems to be proud to say that "we are moving the tax structure for the first time since 1988".
To change for the better is very good, but to change for the worse, damaging the whole nation and the Country, is a disaster that can not be admitted.

I am pleased to deliver a lecture today at the Waseda University of Japan on 'Japan-Africa for TICAD VI'
Japan launched TICAD at a time when many developed world did not care about Africa after the end of the Cold War
African countries need to be assisted to shorten their transition period from least developed to developed countries.
The 5 TICAD Summit were successful. For the first time this year TICAD summit will take place in Africa
I can say with alot of confidence that TICAD has worked well for Africa's interests. Japan has never failed Africa.
Japan ODA to Africa has doubled from 0.9bil USD in 2007 to 1.8bil USD by 2011.FDI has doubled from 3.4bil USD to 6.2bil USD by 2011
African economies have performed better in the past 15 years with East Africa region toppled 6.3% growth which is above Africa average 4.2%
Japan private sector is still lagging in investing in Africa.While Japan FDI to Africa is 10 bil $, it is 20 bil $ to 6 ASEAN countries.
Africa has seen Japanese product made in Japan, its now time to see Japanese Industries manufacturing product in Africa
Japan and Africa can grow together as it was a case with the 'Fly-Geese' partnership between Japan and Asian countries. Time is now!
